The EU was established after World War II to promote political reconciliation and economic prosperity in Europe through a series of binding treaties. In 1952, six European states established the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) to promote peace, stability, and economic growth. This led to the creation of the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1957. In 1957, the six ECSC member states signed two new treaties in Rome: the first established the European Economic Community (EEC) to develop common economic policies and merge national markets into a single market; the second created a European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) for peaceful nuclear energy use. These "Treaties of Rome" came into force in 1958, leading to the formation of the European Community (EC) in 1967. The Treaties of Rome established the European Economic Community (EEC) and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) in 1957. In 1967, they collectively became known as the European Community (EC). The EC expanded with new members in 1973, 1981, 1986, and 1993 with the Treaty on European Union (Maastricht Treaty).
